trans-unit.source: Represents a Windows toolbar.

Although <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStrip"></xref> replaces and adds functionality to the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar"></xref> control of previous versions, <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar"></xref> is retained for both backward compatibility and future use if you choose.

<xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar> controls are used to display <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton> controls that can appear as a standard button, a toggle-style button, or a drop-down style button.

You can assign images to the buttons by creating an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ImageList>, assigning it to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ImageList%2A> property of the toolbar, and assigning the image index value to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton.ImageIndex%2A> property each <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton>.

You can then assign text to be displayed underneath or to the right of the image by setting the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton.Text%2A> property of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton>.
Set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.Appearance%2A> property of the toolbar to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarAppearance.Flat> to give the toolbar and its buttons a flat appearance.
As the mouse pointer moves over the buttons, their appearance changes to three-dimensional.
Toolbar buttons can be divided into logical groups by using separators.
A separator is a toolbar button with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton.Style%2A> property set to `ToolBarButtonStyle.Separator`.
Button separators appear as lines rather than spaces between the buttons when the toolbar has a flat appearance.
If the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.Appearance%2A> property is set to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarAppearance.Normal>, the toolbar buttons appear raised and three-dimensional.
If you specify a value for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ButtonSize%2A> property, all buttons in the tool bar are restricted to the specified size.
Otherwise, the buttons adjust their size depending on their content, and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ButtonSize%2A> property returns the initial size of the largest button.

To create a collection of <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton> controls to display on the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar>, add the buttons individually by using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ToolBarButtonCollection.Add%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ToolBarButtonCollection.Insert%2A> methods of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.Buttons%2A> property.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar"></xref> class.
A newly created toolbar control is empty; add <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton> controls by setting the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.Buttons%2A> property.
Gets or set the value that determines the appearance of a toolbar control and its buttons.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.Appearance%2A> property affects the appearance of the buttons assigned to the toolbar.
When the appearance is set to `ToolBarAppearance.Normal`, the toolbar's buttons appear three-dimensional and raised.
Set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.Appearance%2A> property of the toolbar to `ToolBarAppearance.Flat` to give the toolbar's buttons a flat appearance.
As the mouse pointer moves over the flat buttons, they appear raised and three-dimensional.

Separators on a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar> with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.Appearance%2A> property set to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarAppearance.Flat> appear as etched lines rather than spaces between the raised buttons.
The flat style buttons give your application a more Web-like look.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarAppearance"></xref> values.
The default is `ToolBarAppearance.Normal`.
The assigned value is not one of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarAppearance"></xref> values.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether the toolbar adjusts its size automatically, based on the size of the buttons and the dock style.

When <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.AutoSize%2A> is set to `true`, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar> control sizes itself to accommodate the toolbar buttons, based upon the button size, the number of <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton> objects it contains, and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle> of the toolbar.
`true` if the toolbar adjusts its size automatically, based on the size of the buttons and dock style; otherwise, `false`.
The default is `true`.
Occurs when the value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.AutoSize"></xref> property has changed.
For more information about handling events, see [Handling and Raising Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
Gets or sets the background color.
The background color.
Occurs when the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.BackColor"></xref> property changes.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.BackColor%2A> property is not meaningful for this control, although you can change its value and handle the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.BackColorChanged> event to detect the change.
Gets or sets the background image.
The background image.
Occurs when the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.BackgroundImage"></xref> property changes.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.BackgroundImage%2A> property is not meaningful for this control, although you can change its value and handle the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.BackgroundImageChanged> event to detect the change.
Gets or sets the layout for background image.
The layout for background image.
Occurs when the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.BackgroundImageLayout"></xref> property changes.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.BackgroundImageLayout%2A> property is not meaningful for this control, although you can change its value and handle the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.BackgroundImageLayoutChanged> event to detect the change.
Gets or sets the border style of the toolbar control.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar> can take on a sunken, three-dimensional appearance when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.BorderStyle> property is set to `BorderStyle.Fixed3D`.
To display a flat thin border around the toolbar control, set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.BorderStyle> property to `BorderStyle.FixedSingle`.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.BorderStyle"></xref> values.
The default is `BorderStyle.None`.
The assigned value is not one of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.BorderStyle"></xref> values.
Occurs when a <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton"></xref> on the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar"></xref> is clicked.
For more information about handling events, see [Handling and Raising Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
Occurs when a drop-down style <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton"></xref> or its down arrow is clicked.
For more information about handling events, see [Handling and Raising Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
Gets the collection of <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton"></xref> controls assigned to the toolbar control.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.Buttons%2A> property is a zero-based indexed collection used to hold all the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton> controls assigned to the toolbar.
Because the property is read-only, it can not be assigned a collection of toolbar buttons directly.
Toolbar buttons can be added or removed by using the methods inherited from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ToolBarButtonCollection> class.

Use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ToolBarButtonCollection.Add%2A> method to add individual buttons and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ToolBarButtonCollection.Remove%2A> method to delete a button.
Call the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ToolBarButtonCollection.Clear%2A> method to remove all the buttons from the collection.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ToolBarButtonCollection"></xref> that contains a collection of <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton"></xref> controls.
Gets or sets the size of the buttons on the toolbar control.
If the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ButtonSize%2A> is not set, it is set to its default.
Alternatively, a <xref:System.Drawing.Size> is computed to accommodate the largest <xref:System.Drawing.Image> and text assigned to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton> controls.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Size"></xref> object that represents the size of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton"></xref> controls on the toolbar.
The default size has a width of 24 pixels and a height of 22 pixels, or large enough to accommodate the <xref href="System.Drawing.Image"></xref> and text, whichever is greater.
The <xref href="System.Drawing.Size.Width"></xref> or <xref href="System.Drawing.Size.Height"></xref> property of the <xref href="System.Drawing.Size"></xref> object is less than 0.
Creates a handle for the control.
Gets the required creation parameters when the control handle is created.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.CreateParams"></xref> that contains the required creation parameters when the handle to the control is created.
Gets the default Input Method Editor (IME) mode supported by this control.
As implemented in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar> class, this property always returns the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ImeMode?displayProperty=fullName> value.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ImeMode"></xref> values.
Gets the default size of the control.
The default <xref href="System.Drawing.Size"></xref> of the control.
Releases the unmanaged resources used by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar"></xref> and optionally releases the managed resources.
This method is called by the public `Dispose` method and the <xref:System.Object.Finalize%2A> method.
`Dispose` invokes the protected `Dispose(Boolean)` method with the `disposing` parameter set to `true`.
<xref:System.Object.Finalize%2A> invokes `Dispose` with `disposing` set to `false`.
When the `disposing` parameter is `true`, this method releases all resources held by any managed objects that this <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar> references.
This method invokes the `Dispose` method of each referenced object.
`true` to release both managed and unmanaged resources; `false` to release only unmanaged resources.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether the toolbar displays a divider.
Dividers are displayed to help distinguish the toolbar from adjacent controls, such as menus.
A divider is displayed as a raised edge along the top of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar> control.
`true` if the toolbar displays a divider; otherwise, `false`.
The default is `true`.
Gets or sets which control borders are docked to its parent control and determines how a control is resized with its parent.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle"></xref> values.
The default is <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle.None"></xref>.
This member is not meaningful for this control.
A <xref href="System.Boolean"></xref> value.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether drop-down buttons on a toolbar display down arrows.
When <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.DropDownArrows%2A> is set to `false`, no down arrows display on drop-down style toolbar buttons.
When the user clicks the drop-down button on the toolbar, the menu drops down for selection.
When the drop-down arrow is displayed, the user must press the down arrow to display the menu.
`true` if drop-down toolbar buttons display down arrows; otherwise, `false`.
The default is `false`.
Gets or sets the forecolor .
The forecolor.
Occurs when the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ForeColor"></xref> property changes.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ForeColor%2A> property is not meaningful for this control, although you can change its value and handle the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ForeColorChanged> event to detect the change.
Gets or sets the collection of images available to the toolbar button controls.

If you create an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ImageList> and assign it to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ImageList%2A> property, you can assign an image from the collection to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton> controls by assigning the image's index value to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton.ImageIndex%2A> property of the toolbar button.
An <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ImageList"></xref> that contains images available to the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton"></xref> controls.
The default is `null`.
Gets the size of the images in the image list assigned to the toolbar.

A <xref href="System.Drawing.Size"></xref> that represents the size of the images (in the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ImageList"></xref>) assigned to the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar"></xref>.
This member is not meaningful for this control.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ImeMode"></xref> values.
Occurs when the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ImeMode"></xref> property changes.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ImeMode%2A> property is not meaningful for this control, although you can change its value and handle the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ImeModeChanged> event to detect the change.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ButtonClick"></xref> event.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Handling and Raising Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.OnButtonClick%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButtonClickEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ButtonDropDown"></xref> event.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Handling and Raising Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.OnButtonDropDown%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButtonClickEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.FontChanged"></xref> event.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.OnFontChanged%2A> method resizes the toolbar buttons to fit the size of the new font.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.HandleCreated"></xref> event.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Resize"></xref> event.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
This member is not meaningful for this control.
This member is not meaningful for this control.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.RightToLeft"></xref> value.
Occurs when the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.RightToLeft"></xref> property changes.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.RightToLeft%2A> property is not meaningful for this control, although you can change its value and handle the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.RightToLeftChanged> event to detect the change.
Scales a control's location, size, padding and margin.
The factor by which the height and width of the control will be scaled.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.BoundsSpecified"></xref> value that specifies the bounds of the control to use when defining its size and position.
This method is not relevant for this class.
The horizontal scaling factor.
The vertical scaling factor.
Sets the specified bounds of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar"></xref> control.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.SetBoundsCore%2A> method ignores width if the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.Dock%2A> property is set to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle.Left> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle.Right> and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.AutoSize%2A> property is set to `true`.

<xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.SetBoundsCore%2A> ignores height if the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.Dock%2A> property is set to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle.Top> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle.Bottom> and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.AutoSize%2A> property is set to `true`.
The new `Left` property value of the control.
The new `Top` property value of the control.
The new `Width` property value of the control.
Not used.
A bitwise combination of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.BoundsSpecified"></xref> values.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether the toolbar displays a ToolTip for each button.

To set the text displayed by the ToolTip, set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton.ToolTipText%2A> property of each <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton> on the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar>.
To cause the ToolTip to display as the user moves the mouse pointer over the toolbar button, set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ShowToolTips%2A> property to `true`.
`true` if the toolbar display a ToolTip for each button; otherwise, `false`.
The default is `false`.
This property is not meaningful for this control.
This property is not meaningful for this control.
Gets or sets the text for the toolbar.
The text for the toolbar.
Gets or sets the alignment of text in relation to each image displayed on the toolbar button controls.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton.Text%2A> can be aligned underneath or to the right of the image displayed on the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton> controls.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarTextAlign"></xref> values.
The default is `ToolBarTextAlign.Underneath`.
The assigned value is not one of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarTextAlign"></xref> values.
Occurs when the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.Text"></xref> property changes.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.Text%2A> property is not meaningful for this control, although you can change its value and handle the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.TextChanged> event to detect the change.
Returns a string that represents the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar"></xref> control.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ToString%2A> method returns a string that includes the type, the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ToolBarButtonCollection.Count%2A> property in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ToolBarButtonCollection>, and the string returned by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.ToString%2A> method of the toolbar’s first button.
A String that represents the current <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar"></xref>.
Processes Windows messages.
The Windows <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Message"></xref> to process.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether the toolbar buttons wrap to the next line if the toolbar becomes too small to display all the buttons on the same line.
Toolbar buttons can be divided into logical groups by using separators.
A separator is a toolbar button with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBarButton.Style%2A> property set to `ToolBarButtonStyle.Separator`.

If the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolBar.Wrappable%2A> property is set to `true` and the toolbar becomes too small to display all the buttons on the same line, the toolbar is broken into additional lines, with the breaks occurring at the separators.
This ensures that button groups stay together.
Toolbar buttons that are not in a group can be separated when the toolbar wraps.
The toolbar can become too small to display all its buttons on the same line if its parent <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form> is resized.
`true` if the toolbar buttons wrap to another line if the toolbar becomes too small to display all the buttons on the same line; otherwise, `false`.
The default value is `true`.
